body:
It's something we've absolutely talked about.

We're a little busy getting a 1.0 ready right now, but after that I'm sure
we will.

If anyone has time before then, I'd absolutely be happy to guide them
through what's required to make this happen for C++.

On Fri, Feb 26, 2016, 3:56 AM joelchen notifications@github.com wrote:

> Very much appreciate gRPC supporting FlatBuffers for a slight trade-off in
> wire format size for better performance than Protocol Buffers as
> highlighted in
> http://google.github.io/flatbuffers/flatbuffers_benchmarks.html.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/5438.
@gwvo is working on this

This was the first change to grpc to allow us to share the grpc code generation between Protocol Buffers and FlatBuffers: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/6130

Now working on integrating that with `flatc`.
Very nice!
I have a pending commit that has initial `flatc` codegen integration, but I have not had time to return to it recently. Could benefit from some review/help from grpc team members.

Very nice y'all :)  We're really looking forward to this.  We're using
Flatbufs for file storage as well as our wire format.  We've been
developing using gRPC as our protocol, and had been planning to swap over
to Flatbuffs when ready.  This is really a killer stack at this point, hats
off!  Nice work!

On Thu, Jun 2, 2016 at 2:59 PM, Wouter van Oortmerssen <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I have a pending commit that has initial flatc codegen integration, but I
> have not had time to return to it recently. Could benefit from some
> review/help from grpc team members.
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/5438#issuecomment-223388876, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe/AAADMLmy5W6S4wpJowQktei8dH1p5mn8ks5qHygYgaJpZM4HjuG4
> .

## 

Brian Corrigan
518-867-1439http://oddnetworks.com http://www.oddnetworks.com/New York
That seems to be a great news. We have been using proto3 with grpc. Having flatbuffer with Grpc would be awesome. Eagerly looking forward to it.
Awesome, looking forward to integrate gRPC for mobile games, where flatbuffers shines :-)
Very true!
Commit is in internal review, will soon have something for y'all to look at :)

Ok, first commit with GRPC support has landed in FlatBuffers: https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/commit/48f37f9e0a04f2b60046dda7fef20a8b0ebc1a70

I wouldn't be surprised if this is still rough around the edges, and it certainly needs some improvements still (like making the GRPC path zero-copy).

I'd be grateful for anyone having a look and giving feedback, to see if anything else is needed for people to start using this.
How to start using/testing (experimentation) this grpc implementation? (we are using flatbuffers now and plan to use gRPC soon). Any guideline? Thanks. Just passing --grpc?

There is a simple test case here: https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/blob/master/grpc/tests/grpctest.cpp
Obviously, more thorough testing would be welcome, but I first wanted to get things out there for people to look at.

`--grpc` will generate the interface code, look at the above sample for a way to use it (which is very similar to how C++ is generally used in the GRPC documentation).
Thanks. Starting reviewing that.
It's not immediately clear to me how to do streams in gRPC with flatbuffers. Am I missing something?
I would hope streaming is transparent to the serialization mechanism used, i.e. it will simply supply you multiple buffers, but I haven't looked into this myself.
I was attempting to use the Flatbuffers IDL (and flatc --grpc), but it does not appear to support describing streams. Is there a different approach I should use?
Ah, I totally missed that. I will give it a try. Thanks

It's awesome to see flatbuffers finally able to be sent with grpc. I am currently working with a go project and would like convert it from proto to flatbuffers. When i create a .fbs and run flatc --grpc I get a grpc.fb.cc and a grpc.fb.h, is there currently a way to get the golang equivalent to that?
- 1 I was actually wanting Go support too, I ended up sticking with protobuf and hoping that go flatbuf grpc would arrive soon

Does this require any special flag while building the grpc code (so that we can use flatbuffers)? I am using Visual Studio solution files and looks like the code is linking with protobufs by default. 

How to make the grpc know that (while running) it should expect the data in flatbuffers format and not protobuf? or is grpc smart enough to figure out the format / does not really care about the format and format-neutral

Getting the below error while building the `grpctest` in the flatbuffer solution with visual studio.

```
1>------ Build started: Project: grpctest, Configuration: Debug Win32 ------
1>  grpctest.cpp
1>\tests\monster_test_generated.h(625): warning C4316: 'MyGame::Example::Vec3': object allocated on the heap may not be aligned 16
1>\grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h(308): error C2027: use of undefined type 'grpc::SerializationTraits<R,void>'
1>          with
1>          [
1>              R=flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>
1>          ]
1> \grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h(304): note: while compiling class template member function 'void grpc::CallOpRecvMessage<R>::FinishOp(bool *,int)'
1>          with
1>          [
1>              R=flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>
1>          ]
1>  \grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h(613): note: see reference to function template instantiation 'void grpc::CallOpRecvMessage<R>::FinishOp(bool *,int)' being compiled
1>          with
1>          [
1>              R=flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>
1>          ]
1>  \grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h(595): note: see reference to class template instantiation 'grpc::CallOpRecvMessage<R>' being compiled
1>          with
1>          [
1>              R=flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>
1>          ]
1>  \grpc++/impl/codegen/async_unary_call.h(111): note: see reference to class template instantiation 'grpc::CallOpSet<grpc::CallOpRecvInitialMetadata,grpc::CallOpRecvMessage<R>,grpc::CallOpClientRecvStatus,grpc::CallNoOp<4>,grpc::CallNoOp<5>,grpc::CallNoOp<6>>' being compiled
1>          with
1>          [
1>              R=flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>
1>          ]
1>  \grpc++/impl/codegen/async_unary_call.h(88): note: see reference to class template instantiation 'grpc::ClientAsyncResponseReader<flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>>::CallOpSetCollection' being compiled
1>  \grpc++/impl/codegen/async_unary_call.h(87): note: while compiling class template member function 'void grpc::ClientAsyncResponseReader<flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>>::Finish(R *,grpc::Status *,void *)'
1>          with
1>          [
1>              R=flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>
1>          ]
1>  \tests\monster_test.grpc.fb.h(64): note: see reference to class template instantiation 'grpc::ClientAsyncResponseReader<flatbuffers::BufferRef<MyGame::Example::Stat>>' being compiled
1>\grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h(308): error C3861: 'Deserialize': identifier not found
1>\grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h(310): error C2228: left of '.ok' must have class/struct/union
1>  \grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h(310): note: type is 'unknown-type'
```

GRPC is still dependent on ProtoBuf in other places. Using it with FlatBuffers is largely driven from the generated code within the FlatBuffers project.

I have never compiled `grpctest` with Visual Studio, since at the time GRPC didn't support VS, but it looks like it does now?

`grpc::SerializationTraits` is defined in `flatbuffers/grpc.h`, so I'm not sure why that is an error here, but not in Linux.
Also looks the CMake link library definition for `grpctest` may be *nix specific..
any ETA on when flatbuffers will be supported in Java?
@rajc : Noone is actively working on Java support, as far as I know. Contributions welcome.
@ejona86 @iamqizhao This issue was cleaned up in today's bug scrub. Is this feature implemented in Java and/or Go? Should it be?
It is not implemented in Java.
